content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}
Now given a task: Find a Mexico hotel with deals for December 25-26.  Please interact with https://www.booking.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find a Mexico hotel with deals for December 25-26, I should first enter "Mexico" in the location textbox to start the search process.
Action: Type [14]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The location is currently set to "Niagara Falls". I need to adjust the search for Mexico and also select the correct check-in and check-out dates. To proceed, I must scroll or click "Next month" to reach December 2024, since the current calendar shows only September and October 2025.
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I still need to reach December 2024 for the correct dates for the task (December 25-26). The calendar currently shows October and November 2025, so I need to continue viewing earlier months by clicking "Previous month".
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still on September and October 2025. I need to keep going back month by month to reach December 2024 for the correct check-in date.
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still not showing December 2024 (currently October and November 2025). To proceed, I must continue to click "Previous month" to move the calendar back to the right date range.
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is again displaying September and October 2025. I am not making progress toward December 2024, which means I should look for a different way to reach earlier months, such as a "Previous month" button. The current action of clicking [18] moves forward rather than backward. I need to find the appropriate button to go back through the months instead.
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still on October and November 2025. To find December 2024, I need to keep going backward. The "Previous month" button is labeled [18] and should be clicked repeatedly until the right month appears.
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar view has looped back to September and October 2025, indicating the navigation is stuck between these months. I need to search for an alternative way to access previous years or reset the date selection. The next step is to interact with the calendar settings to see if there's a way to jump years instead of months, possibly by clicking the "Calendar" button.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still showing only September and October 2025, indicating no successful navigation to December 2024. The problem is rooted in the location set to "Niagara Falls" and not "Mexico." To resolve, I should first change the destination in the "Where are you going?" textbox so that subsequent searches are for Mexico.
Action: Type [13]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search location remains set to "Niagara Falls" even after attempting to type "Mexico". Likely, I need to confirm or select Mexico after entering it, or select it from a dropdown list that appears after text entry. The next best step is to click the search button to trigger the search for Mexico if it's already been typed.
Action: Click [99]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search location is still "Niagara Falls," indicating that just typing "Mexico" was not enough—either a dropdown appeared and wasn't selected, or the input was not confirmed properly. I should try to clear the textbox and re-type "Mexico" carefully to trigger the right location search.
Action: Type [13]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination input still shows "Niagara Falls," meaning the location hasn't changed to "Mexico." The location needs to be updated to "Mexico" for the search to be valid. Typically, after typing a new location in the textbox, selecting from a suggested dropdown or clicking a confirm/add button is required. There is a button next to the textbox ([14]) which should be clicked to potentially clear or update/select the location.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4

Thought: The location textbox is now empty with trending destinations dropdown open (Niagara Falls, Toronto, Montreal, Ottawa, Quebec City), but "Mexico" is not listed. I should type "Mexico" in the location textbox ([13]) to get relevant destination suggestions for Mexico.
Action: Type [13]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.5
